markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

crosscut.com  (WEB - en-US)

A nonprofit news website focused on investigative and feature reporting on politics and culture in Seattle and the state of Washington.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

Crosscut is a division of Cascade Public Media, a nonprofit organization based in Seattle. Cascade also owns KCTS-TV, a public PBS-affiliated television station in Seattle.

Crosscut is funded by donations, advertising, and events.

Content

The site publishes original articles focusing on politics and cultural issues in Seattle and Washington state. Content is organized into sections for Politics, Culture, Equity, Environment, and Opinion. Typical stories have included, “Under threat from Trump, transgender community leans on local rights” and “Seattle considers $3M tent to shelter homeless.” The site also produces original video reports, housed in a Multimedia section.

Crosscut often conducts in-depth reporting, such as a two-part series published in January 2018 that exposed mismanagement in the City of Seattle’s human resources department.

Credibility

Crosscut’s articles are typically well-reported, citing reliable sources, first-hand interviews, reports from top news outlets, and primary source documents. Headlines are straightforward and representative of content. Commentary articles, representing a range of views, reside in a separate section and are labeled “opinion.”

Crosscut runs corrections, in the form of a note at the bottom stories explaining how the error was corrected.  

Transparency

Stories name their author at the top and bottom, and link to a page that often contains a photograph, biography, and contact information. The About section provides biographical and contact information for all of the outlet’s employees as well as information about its financing. Under its donor transparency policy, the organization discloses all donors who gave $5,000 or more annually.

The site’s About page states that Crosscut upholds the Institute for Nonprofit News’ standards of editorial independence. “As a nonprofit, we will avoid accepting donations from anonymous sources, and we will not accept donations from government entities, political parties, elected officials or candidates actively seeking public office,” the site states. “We will not accept donations from sources who, deemed by our board of directors, present a conflict of interest with our work or compromise our independence.”

Advertisements and sponsored content are clearly labeled.

History

Crosscut was launched in 2007 by David Brewster, a founder of the alternative weekly newspaper Seattle Weekly. Crosscut began as a for-profit venture backed by investors, but announced in 2008 that it would become a nonprofit following financial troubles. The publication merged with public television station KCTS 9 in 2015, forming Cascade Public Media.

Written by:
Jack Craver

Edited by:
Sarah Brandt Eric Effron
